api2.updated_html:
SHAREHOLDERS' AGREEMENT

This Shareholders' Agreement (this "Agreement") is made and entered into as of this [Day] day of [Month], [Year] (the "Effective Date"),

BY AND AMONG:

[COMPANY NAME], a corporation duly incorporated under the laws of [Jurisdiction of Incorporation], with its registered office located at [Company Address] (the "Company").

AND:

[SHAREHOLDER 1 NAME], an individual residing at [Shareholder 1 Address], holding [Number] Common Shares and [Number] Preferred Shares in the Company (the "Shareholder 1").

AND:

[SHAREHOLDER 2 NAME], an individual residing at [Shareholder 2 Address], holding [Number] Common Shares and [Number] Preferred Shares in the Company (the "Shareholder 2").

(Each of the Company, Shareholder 1, and Shareholder 2 hereinafter referred to individually as a "Party" and collectively as the "Parties").

1. DEFINITIONS

For the purposes of this Agreement, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them below, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. "Shares" shall mean all shares in the capital of the Company, including both Common Shares and Preferred Shares, whether currently issued or hereafter issued. This definition encompasses any and all equity interests, options, warrants, or other securities convertible into or exchangeable for shares, representing ownership in the Company, and includes any future subdivisions, consolidations, or reclassifications thereof.

"Board" or "Board of Directors" refers to the duly constituted board of directors of the Company, responsible for the overall governance and strategic direction of the Company. "Confidential Information" means all non-public information, whether commercial, financial, technical, operational, or otherwise, disclosed by one Party to another, or otherwise obtained by a Party in connection with the Company's business, which is marked as confidential or which, by its nature, would reasonably be understood to be confidential. This includes, but is not limited to, business plans, customer lists, financial data, product designs, and software code.

2. SHARE CLASSES AND CAPITAL STRUCTURE

The authorized share capital of the Company shall consist of [Number] Common Shares, with a par value of $[Amount] per share, and [Number] Preferred Shares, with a par value of $[Amount] per share. The Common Shares shall generally carry one vote per share and be entitled to dividends after the Preferred Shares. The Preferred Shares shall have specific rights, including but not limited to, a liquidation preference of $[Amount] per share, non-cumulative dividends at a rate of [Percentage]% per annum, and such other rights as set forth in the Company's Articles of Incorporation.

No additional shares of any class or series shall be issued by the Company without the prior written consent of Shareholders holding at least [Percentage]% of the then-issued and outstanding Common Shares and [Percentage]% of the then-issued and outstanding Preferred Shares, voting as separate classes. Any new issuance of shares shall be subject to the pre-emptive rights of existing Shareholders as detailed in Section 6, ensuring that each Shareholder has the opportunity to maintain their proportionate ownership interest in the Company.

3. BOARD OF DIRECTORS

The Board of Directors of the Company shall consist of a minimum of [Number] and a maximum of [Number] directors. Shareholder 1 shall have the right to designate [Number] director(s) to the Board, and Shareholder 2 shall have the right to designate [Number] director(s) to the Board. Any remaining director positions shall be mutually agreed upon by the Shareholders. Directors shall be elected annually at the Company's general meeting of shareholders.

A director may be removed from the Board, with or without cause, by the Shareholder(s) who designated such director, or by a unanimous vote of all other directors and a majority vote of the Shareholders. The Board shall be responsible for the strategic oversight and governance of the Company, including but not limited to, approving annual budgets, major capital expenditures, and the appointment of senior management. A quorum for any Board meeting shall be [Number] directors, and resolutions shall be passed by a simple majority vote of directors present, unless otherwise specified herein or in the Company's bylaws.

4. VOTING RIGHTS

Except as otherwise provided in the Company's Articles of Incorporation or this Agreement, all resolutions requiring Shareholder approval shall be passed by a simple majority of the votes cast by the Common Shares and Preferred Shares, voting together as a single class. However, certain "Reserved Matters," as defined below, shall require the affirmative vote of Shareholders holding at least [Percentage]% of the Common Shares and [Percentage]% of the Preferred Shares, voting as separate classes, or the unanimous written consent of all Shareholders.

Reserved Matters shall include, but not be limited to, any amendment to the Company's Articles of Incorporation or Bylaws, any issuance of new shares, any merger, consolidation, sale of all or substantially all of the Company's assets, liquidation or dissolution of the Company, incurrence of indebtedness exceeding $[Amount], or the declaration of any dividends. Any action taken by the Company or the Board concerning a Reserved Matter without the requisite Shareholder approval shall be null and void and of no effect.

5. DIVIDENDS AND DISTRIBUTIONS

The Company shall, at the discretion of the Board, declare and pay dividends or make other distributions to its Shareholders, subject to applicable law and the Company's Articles of Incorporation. Preferred Shareholders shall have a preference in the payment of dividends at the rate specified in Section 2 before any dividends are paid to Common Shareholders. Any declaration of dividends shall be made in accordance with the Company's financial performance and cash flow projections, ensuring the Company retains sufficient working capital for its operations and growth initiatives.

The Board shall review the Company's financial position at least annually to determine the feasibility and appropriateness of declaring dividends. Notwithstanding any other provision, no dividends or distributions shall be declared or paid if, in the reasonable opinion of the Board, such payment would render the Company insolvent or would cause the Company to be in breach of any loan covenants or other material contractual obligations. Any dividends declared shall be paid pro rata to the holders of each class of shares entitled thereto, based on their respective shareholdings.

6. TRANSFER RESTRICTIONS AND EXIT TERMS

No Shareholder shall sell, assign, transfer, encumber, or otherwise dispose of any Shares in the Company without strict compliance with the provisions of this Agreement. Before any Shareholder (the "Selling Shareholder") can transfer Shares to a third party, the Selling Shareholder must first offer such Shares to the other Shareholders (the "Non-Selling Shareholders") in accordance with a right of first refusal. The Non-Selling Shareholders shall have [Number] days to elect to purchase their pro rata portion of the offered shares at the price and on the terms offered by the third party.

In the event that a third party offers to purchase all or substantially all of the shares of the Company (a "Drag-Along Event"), and Shareholders holding at least [Percentage]% of the issued and outstanding Common Shares and [Percentage]% of the issued and outstanding Preferred Shares agree to such sale, then all other Shareholders shall be obligated to sell all of their shares on the same terms and conditions as the selling Shareholders. Conversely, if a Selling Shareholder proposes to sell shares to a third party, the Non-Selling Shareholders shall have the right (a "Tag-Along Right") to participate in such sale on a pro rata basis and on the same terms and conditions as the Selling Shareholder.

7. CONFIDENTIALITY

Each Shareholder acknowledges that, in connection with their ownership of Shares and participation in the Company's affairs, they may obtain or have access to Confidential Information. Each Shareholder agrees to keep all Confidential Information strictly confidential and not to disclose, disseminate, or use such Confidential Information for any purpose other than for the benefit of the Company, without the prior written consent of the Company or as required by law. This obligation of confidentiality shall survive the termination of this Agreement or the Shareholder's ownership of Shares.

The confidentiality obligations shall not apply to information that (a) is or becomes publicly available through no fault of the receiving Shareholder; (b) was already in the receiving Shareholder's possession prior to disclosure by the Company, without breach of any confidentiality obligation; (c) is independently developed by the receiving Shareholder without use of or reference to the Company's Confidential Information; or (d) is required to be disclosed by law, regulation, or court order, provided that the receiving Shareholder gives prompt notice to the Company prior to such disclosure.

8. REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES

Each Shareholder severally represents and warrants to the Company and the other Shareholders that: (a) they have the full power and authority to enter into and perform their obligations under this Agreement; (b) this Agreement constitutes a legal, valid, and binding obligation, enforceable against them in accordance with its terms; (c) their execution and delivery of this Agreement does not violate any other agreement or instrument to which they are a party; and (d) they are the sole legal and beneficial owner of the Shares listed opposite their name, free and clear of all liens, encumbrances, and adverse claims.

The Company represents and warrants to each Shareholder that: (a) it is duly incorporated, validly existing, and in good standing under the laws of its jurisdiction of incorporation; (b) it has the corporate power and authority to enter into and perform its obligations under this Agreement; and (c) this Agreement constitutes a legal, valid, and binding obligation of the Company, enforceable against it in accordance with its terms. These representations and warranties are fundamental to the Agreement and shall survive the execution and delivery of this Agreement.

9. INDEMNIFICATION

Each Shareholder agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the Company, its directors, officers, employees, and agents, and the other Shareholders, from and against any and all losses, damages, liabilities, costs, and expenses (including reasonable attorneys' fees) arising from or in connection with any breach by such Shareholder of any of their representations, warranties, covenants, or obligations under this Agreement. This indemnification obligation shall be proportional to the breaching Shareholder's fault and shall be capped at the value of the Shares held by the breaching Shareholder, unless the breach involves fraud or willful misconduct.

The Company agrees to indemnify and hold harmless each Shareholder, their respective directors, officers, employees, and agents, from and against any and all losses, damages, liabilities, costs, and expenses (including reasonable attorneys' fees) arising from or in connection with any breach by the Company of any of its representations, warranties, covenants, or obligations under this Agreement. Prompt written notice of any claim for indemnification must be provided to the indemnifying Party, and the indemnifying Party shall have the right to assume the defense of any such claim with counsel of its own choosing.

10. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY

Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement, no Party shall be liable to any other Party for any indirect, incidental, consequential, special, punitive, or exemplary damages, including, but not limited to, loss of profits, revenue, data, or business opportunity, arising out of or in connection with this Agreement, even if such Party has been advised of the possibility of such damages. This limitation applies regardless of the form of action, whether in contract, tort (including negligence), strict liability, or otherwise.

The aggregate liability of any Shareholder under this Agreement for any and all claims, damages, or causes of action arising hereunder, excluding claims related to fraud, willful misconduct, or gross negligence, shall not exceed the fair market value of the Shares held by such Shareholder at the time of the breach. This limitation of liability is a fundamental element of the basis of the bargain between the Parties and reflects the allocation of risk between them.

11. TERM AND TERMINATION

This Agreement shall commence on the Effective Date and shall continue in full force and effect until the earliest of: (a) the mutual written agreement of all Parties; (b) the dissolution or winding up of the Company; (c) the Company becoming a publicly traded company through an initial public offering; or (d) such time as only one Shareholder remains, at which point the purpose of this Agreement would cease to exist.

Upon termination of this Agreement, the rights and obligations of the Parties hereunder shall cease, except for those provisions which, by their nature, are intended to survive termination, including but not limited to, Sections 1 (Definitions), 7 (Confidentiality), 9 (Indemnification), 10 (Limitation of Liability), 12 (Governing Law), 13 (Dispute Resolution), and 14 (Miscellaneous Provisions). Termination of this Agreement shall not relieve any Party of liability for any breach of this Agreement occurring prior to such termination.

12. GOVERNING LAW

This Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of [Jurisdiction], without regard to its conflict of laws principles. The Parties expressly agree that the United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods shall not apply to this Agreement. This choice of law is intended to be comprehensive and to govern all aspects of this Agreement, including its validity, interpretation, performance, and enforcement.

The Parties acknowledge and agree that the chosen jurisdiction's laws provide a well-established and predictable legal framework for the interpretation and enforcement of commercial agreements. Any legal action or proceeding arising under this Agreement shall be brought exclusively in the courts located in [City, Jurisdiction], and the Parties hereby irrevocably consent to the personal jurisdiction and venue of such courts.

13. DISPUTE RESOLUTION

Any dispute, controversy, or claim arising out of or relating to this Agreement, or the breach, termination, or validity thereof, shall first be attempted to be resolved through good faith negotiations between the Parties. If the dispute cannot be resolved through negotiation within [Number] days of written notice of the dispute, the Parties agree to attempt to resolve the dispute through mediation administered by [Mediation Body/Rules] in [City, Jurisdiction], with a mediator mutually agreed upon by the Parties.

If mediation is unsuccessful in resolving the dispute within [Number] days, the dispute shall be finally settled by binding arbitration administered by [Arbitration Body/Rules] in accordance with its then-current rules, conducted in [City, Jurisdiction]. The arbitration shall be conducted by a single arbitrator appointed in accordance with the said rules. The language of the arbitration shall be English. The decision of the arbitrator shall be final and binding upon the Parties and may be entered as a judgment in any court of competent jurisdiction.

14. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

14.1 Entire Agreement. This Agreement, together with the Company's Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws, constitutes the entire agreement between the Parties with respect to the subject matter hereof and supersedes all prior and contemporaneous agreements, understandings, negotiations, and discussions, whether oral or written, of the Parties. No Party has relied on any representation or warranty not expressly set forth in this Agreement.

14.2 Amendments. This Agreement may not be amended, modified, or supplemented except by an instrument in writing signed by all Parties hereto. Any purported amendment, modification, or supplement not made in accordance with this Section shall be null and void and of no effect.

14.3 Notices. All notices, requests, demands, and other communications required or permitted hereunder shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been duly given when delivered personally, sent by reputable overnight courier, or sent by email with confirmation of receipt, to the addresses set forth at the beginning of this Agreement or such other address as a Party may designate by written notice to the other Parties.

14.4 Severability. If any provision of this Agreement is held to be invalid, illegal, or unenforceable in any respect, such invalidity, illegality, or unenforceability shall not affect any other provision hereof, and this Agreement shall be construed as if such invalid, illegal, or unenforceable provision had never been contained herein, provided that the essential purposes of this Agreement are not thereby frustrated.

14.5 Assignment. This Agreement shall be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Parties hereto and their respective heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors, and permitted assigns. No Party may assign any of its rights or obligations hereunder without the prior written consent of all other Parties.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Parties have executed this Shareholders' Agreement as of the Effective Date first above written.

[COMPANY NAME]

By: _________________________

Name: [Authorized Signatory Name]

Title: [Authorized Signatory Title]

[SHAREHOLDER 1 NAME]

By: _________________________

Name: [Shareholder 1 Name]

[SHAREHOLDER 2 NAME]

By: _________________________

Name: [Shareholder 2 Name]

query: Draft Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws for a [state] C Corporation including purpose, share structure, director responsibilities, and procedures for meetings.

api1.updated_html:
ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION AND BYLAWS OF [CORPORATION NAME], INC.

These Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws, hereinafter collectively referred to as the "Governing Documents," are hereby adopted and established for [CORPORATION NAME], Inc., a C Corporation to be organized under the laws of the State of [State]. These Governing Documents shall define the fundamental structure, purpose, and operational procedures of the Corporation, ensuring compliance with all applicable statutes and regulations of the State of [State] and federal law.

The purpose of these Governing Documents is to formally establish the legal existence of the Corporation, delineate its corporate powers, specify its authorized share structure, including classes and series of stock, and set forth the rights and responsibilities of its shareholders, directors, and officers. Furthermore, these documents shall govern the conduct of corporate affairs, including but not limited to, procedures for shareholder and board meetings, election of directors, amendment processes, and the distribution of assets upon dissolution.

This comprehensive framework is designed to provide clarity, stability, and legal enforceability for the Corporation's governance and operations, effective as of [Effective Date].

1. Definitions

For the purposes of these Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them below, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise:

"Articles of Incorporation" shall mean this foundational document, as originally filed with the Secretary of State of [State], and as may be amended from time to time in accordance with applicable law and the provisions herein. This document establishes the legal existence of the Corporation and sets forth its fundamental characteristics.

"Bylaws" shall mean the internal rules and regulations adopted by the Corporation for the governance of its affairs, the management of its business, and the conduct of its members, directors, and officers, as adopted or amended by the Board of Directors or Shareholders from time to time.

"Corporation" or "Company" shall refer to [Corporation Name], a C Corporation duly organized and existing under the laws of the State of [State], which is the subject of these Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws.

"Board of Directors" or "Directors" shall mean the governing body of the Corporation, elected by the Shareholders, responsible for the overall management and strategic direction of the Corporation's business and affairs, as provided by these Bylaws and applicable law.

"Shareholders" shall mean the registered holders of record of the Corporation's issued and outstanding Shares, possessing the rights and obligations as set forth in these Articles of Incorporation, the Bylaws, and the applicable corporate statutes of [State].

"Shares" or "Stock" shall mean the units of ownership interest in the Corporation, representing an equity stake and conferring upon the holder certain rights, including but not limited to, voting rights, dividend rights, and liquidation rights, as defined by the Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws.

"Effective Date" shall mean [Effective Date], the date upon which these Articles of Incorporation are filed with the Secretary of State of [State] and become legally effective, thereby establishing the Corporation's legal existence.

2. Term

The corporate existence of [Corporation Name], as established by the Articles of Incorporation filed with the Secretary of State of [State], shall be perpetual, commencing upon the filing date of said Articles of Incorporation, unless dissolved earlier in accordance with the provisions of applicable [State] corporation law. These Bylaws shall become effective immediately upon their adoption by the Incorporator(s) or the initial Board of Directors on [Effective Date], and shall remain in full force and effect continuously thereafter until duly amended, restated, or repealed in accordance with the procedures set forth herein and the provisions of the [State] Business Corporation Act. The terms and conditions contained within these Bylaws shall govern the internal affairs of the Corporation and the conduct of its business and operations from the aforementioned effective date forward, binding upon all shareholders, directors, and officers of the Corporation.

3. Payment Terms

In consideration for the comprehensive legal services rendered by [Law Firm Name] (hereinafter, "Service Provider") to [Client Company Name] (hereinafter, "Client") for the drafting of the Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws for a [State] C Corporation, the Client agrees to pay the Service Provider a total fixed fee of [Total Fixed Fee Amount], payable in United States Dollars (USD).

Payment shall be structured as follows: an initial retainer of [Initial Retainer Percentage]% of the total fixed fee, amounting to [Initial Retainer Amount], shall be due and payable by the Client upon the execution of this Agreement. The remaining balance of [Remaining Balance Amount] shall be due upon the successful completion and delivery of the final draft Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws to the Client, but no later than [Number] days from the date of such delivery.

All invoices issued by the Service Provider are due upon receipt. In the event of late payment, the Client agrees to pay interest on any overdue amounts at a rate of [Interest Rate]% per month, compounded monthly, or the maximum rate permitted by law, whichever is less, calculated from the due date until the date payment is received in full. Services may be suspended without prior notice if payment is not received within [Number] days of the due date.

The fixed fee explicitly excludes any third-party filing fees, governmental charges, courier costs, or other disbursements incurred on behalf of the Client, which shall be separately itemized and invoiced to the Client for reimbursement. The Client shall be responsible for all applicable taxes, including but not limited to sales tax or value-added tax, if any, imposed on the services provided hereunder.

4. Confidentiality

All information, documents, drafts, discussions, and materials, whether written or oral, including but not limited to the proposed corporate structure, share distribution, director responsibilities, meeting procedures, and any financial or strategic details disclosed by [Client Name] to [Law Firm Name] or developed by [Law Firm Name] during the engagement for drafting the Articles of Incorporation, Bylaws, and related corporate governance documents (collectively, "Confidential Information") shall be treated as strictly confidential.

[Law Firm Name] covenants and agrees to use the Confidential Information solely for the purpose of fulfilling its obligations under this Agreement and shall not, directly or indirectly, disclose, disseminate, or otherwise make available such Confidential Information to any third party without the prior written consent of [Client Name].

Notwithstanding the foregoing, [Law Firm Name] may disclose Confidential Information if compelled by law, court order, or governmental regulation, provided that [Law Firm Name] provides prompt written notice to [Client Name] prior to such disclosure, wherever legally permissible, to allow [Client Name] to seek a protective order or other appropriate remedy. Disclosure may also be made to [Law Firm Name]'s professional advisors (e.g., accountants, other legal counsel) who are themselves bound by similar confidentiality obligations and whose knowledge of the Confidential Information is necessary for the performance of services hereunder.

This obligation of confidentiality shall survive the termination of this Agreement for a period of [Number] years from the [Effective Date], or indefinitely for any information constituting a trade secret under applicable law.

Upon the termination or expiration of this Agreement, [Law Firm Name] shall, at the option and direction of [Client Name], promptly return or destroy all Confidential Information, including all copies thereof, and certify such destruction in writing to [Client Name] within [Number] days of such request.

5. Intellectual Property

All intellectual property, including but not limited to inventions, discoveries, patents, copyrights, trademarks, trade secrets, know-how, and other proprietary rights, whether patentable or unpatentable, registrable or unregistrable, developed, conceived, reduced to practice, or acquired by the Corporation, its officers, directors, employees, or agents in the course of and within the scope of their duties for the Corporation, shall be the sole and exclusive property of the Corporation. The Corporation shall have the right to secure, hold, protect, enforce, and dispose of such intellectual property rights in its own name and for its own benefit.

Furthermore, the Corporation shall have the power to acquire, hold, license, and dispose of intellectual property rights from third parties, consistent with its corporate purpose and the laws of the State of [state]. All officers, directors, and employees shall be required, as a condition of their engagement or employment, to execute agreements assigning to the Corporation any intellectual property developed by them within the scope of their corporate duties and to assist the Corporation in perfecting its rights therein, including but not limited to executing all necessary documents and providing reasonable cooperation.

6. Warranties

[Service Provider] hereby warrants and represents to [Client] that the services rendered under this Agreement, including but not limited to the drafting of the Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws for the proposed [State] C Corporation, shall be performed in a professional and workmanlike manner, exercising the degree of skill and care ordinarily exercised by competent professionals providing similar services under similar circumstances as of the [Effective Date].

[Service Provider] further warrants that, as of the date of delivery to [Client], the drafted Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws will, to the best of [Service Provider]'s knowledge and based on the information provided by [Client], comply with the then-current applicable provisions of the corporate laws of the State of [State] and will be suitable for the purpose of legally forming and governing a C Corporation in [State] upon proper execution, filing, and adoption by [Client].

This warranty is strictly limited to the drafting services provided and does not extend to any subsequent changes in law, or to any inaccuracies or omissions in information supplied by [Client] that form the basis of the drafted documents. [Client] acknowledges and agrees that it bears sole responsibility for reviewing, verifying, and approving the final form of the drafted documents prior to their submission to any governmental authority or internal adoption.

7. Indemnification

The Corporation shall, to the fullest extent permitted by the provisions of the [State] General Corporation Law, as the same may be amended from time to time, indemnify any person who was or is a party or is threatened to be made a party to any threatened, pending, or completed action, suit, or proceeding, whether civil, criminal, administrative, or investigative (other than an action by or in the right of the Corporation) by reason of the fact that he or she is or was a director, officer, employee, or agent of the Corporation, or is or was serving at the request of the Corporation as a director, officer, employee, or agent of another corporation, partnership, joint venture, trust, or other enterprise, against expenses (including attorneys' fees), judgments, fines, and amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred by him or her in connection with such action, suit, or proceeding.

Such indemnification shall be made if such person acted in good faith and in a manner he or she reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interests of the Corporation, and, with respect to any criminal action or proceeding, had no reasonable cause to believe his or her conduct was unlawful. The termination of any action, suit, or proceeding by judgment, order, settlement, conviction, or upon a plea of nolo contendere or its equivalent, shall not, of itself, create a presumption that the person did not act in good faith and in a manner which he or she reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interests of the Corporation, and, with respect to any criminal action or proceeding, had reasonable cause to believe that his or her conduct was unlawful.

The Corporation shall have the power to pay expenses incurred by any such person in defending any such action, suit, or proceeding in advance of its final disposition upon receipt of an undertaking by or on behalf of such person to repay such amount if it shall ultimately be determined that he or she is not entitled to be indemnified by the Corporation as authorized in these Bylaws. The indemnification and advancement of expenses provided by this Section 7 shall not be deemed exclusive of any other rights to which those seeking indemnification or advancement of expenses may be entitled under any bylaw, agreement, vote of stockholders or disinterested directors, or otherwise, and shall continue as to a person who has ceased to be a director, officer, employee, or agent and shall inure to the benefit of the heirs, executors, and administrators of such a person.

8. Limitation of Liability

To the fullest extent permitted by the laws of the State of [State], no director or officer of the Corporation shall be personally liable to the Corporation or its shareholders for monetary damages for breach of fiduciary duty as a director or officer. This limitation of liability shall not apply to the liability of a director or officer for: (i) any breach of the director's or officer's duty of loyalty to the Corporation or its shareholders; (ii) acts or omissions not in good faith or which involve intentional misconduct or a knowing violation of law; (iii) unlawful distributions, loans, or guarantees made in violation of Section [Applicable State Statute Number, e.g., 170.062] of the [State] General Corporation Law; or (iv) any transaction from which the director or officer derived an improper personal benefit. The Corporation shall indemnify its directors and officers to the maximum extent permitted by the laws of the State of [State], including the advancement of expenses, against all liability and expenses incurred in connection with any proceeding arising out of their status as directors or officers, provided such person acted in good faith and in a manner reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interests of the Corporation, and, with respect to any criminal action or proceeding, had no reasonable cause to believe their conduct was unlawful. The rights to indemnification and advancement of expenses provided herein shall not be deemed exclusive of any other rights to which those seeking indemnification or advancement of expenses may be entitled under any statute, bylaw, agreement, vote of shareholders or disinterested directors, or otherwise.

9. Termination

This Agreement, pertaining to the professional services for drafting Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws for a [State] C Corporation, may be terminated prior to the full completion of all specified services under the following conditions:

9.1 Termination for Cause. Either [Party A] or [Client Party] may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice to the other Party if the other Party commits a material breach of any of its obligations, covenants, or representations under this Agreement and fails to cure such breach within [Number] calendar days after receiving written notice thereof from the non-breaching Party. A material breach shall include, but not be limited to, [Party A]'s failure to deliver the completed drafts by the agreed-upon deadline, or [Client Party]'s failure to make timely payments as stipulated in Section [Payment Section Number] of this Agreement.

9.2 Termination for Convenience. [Client Party] may terminate this Agreement for its convenience at any time by providing [Number] calendar days' prior written notice to [Party A]. In the event of such termination, [Client Party] shall pay [Party A] for all services rendered and expenses reasonably incurred up to the effective date of termination, calculated on a pro-rata basis according to the agreed-upon fee schedule, in addition to any non-cancellable commitments made by [Party A] in reliance on this Agreement.

9.3 Effect of Termination. Upon the effective date of termination for any reason, [Party A] shall immediately cease all work related to the drafting of the Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws, and [Client Party] shall promptly pay all outstanding fees and expenses due up to the termination date. All intellectual property rights in work product completed and paid for up to the termination date shall transfer to [Client Party]. Sections related to confidentiality, indemnification, limitations of liability, and dispute resolution shall survive any termination or expiration of this Agreement.

Please review the documents to ensure they align with your specific requirements and state regulations. Let me know if there's anything else you need.

api2.updated_html:
ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION
OF [CORPORATION NAME]

The undersigned, for the purpose of forming a corporation under the General Corporation Law of the State of Delaware, does hereby certify as follows:

ARTICLE I: NAME

The name of the corporation is [CORPORATION NAME]. This name shall be used consistently in all corporate filings, communications, and legal instruments. The corporation reserves the right to change its name in accordance with applicable Delaware law and these Articles, provided such change is properly approved by the Board of Directors and, if required, by the stockholders, and duly filed with the Secretary of State of Delaware.

The chosen name is intended to clearly identify the entity and distinguish it from other corporations registered in the State of Delaware. Any future amendments to this Article I must adhere strictly to the procedural requirements for amending Articles of Incorporation as set forth in the General Corporation Law of Delaware, including the necessity of a board resolution and, where applicable, a stockholder vote, followed by the filing of a Certificate of Amendment.

ARTICLE II: REGISTERED AGENT AND OFFICE

The address of the corporation's registered office in the State of Delaware is [REGISTERED OFFICE ADDRESS, e.g., 1209 Orange Street, Wilmington, New Castle County, Delaware 19801]. The name of its registered agent at such address is [REGISTERED AGENT NAME, e.g., The Corporation Trust Company]. This registered office and agent are designated for the purpose of receiving service of process and official notices on behalf of the corporation, ensuring compliance with statutory requirements for maintaining a presence within the state of incorporation.

The corporation shall maintain a registered agent and registered office in Delaware at all times as required by the General Corporation Law of Delaware. Any change in the registered agent or registered office must be effected by filing a Certificate of Change of Registered Agent and/or Registered Office with the Secretary of State of Delaware. Failure to maintain a valid registered agent and office may result in the forfeiture of the corporation's corporate status or other penalties under Delaware law.

ARTICLE III: PURPOSE

The purpose of the corporation is to engage in any lawful act or activity for which corporations may be organized under the General Corporation Law of Delaware. This broad purpose clause grants the corporation maximum flexibility to pursue various business ventures and activities without the need for frequent amendments to its Articles of Incorporation, encompassing any and all commercial, financial, or other lawful undertakings that the Board of Directors deems appropriate and beneficial to the corporation and its stockholders.

This general purpose clause is intended to be interpreted expansively, allowing the corporation to adapt to changing market conditions and pursue new opportunities without statutory limitations on its scope of operations. While the corporation may initially focus on specific activities, this clause ensures that it is not restricted from expanding into new industries or engaging in diverse business operations, provided such activities remain lawful and are conducted in accordance with the corporation's bylaws and applicable legal and regulatory frameworks.

ARTICLE IV: AUTHORIZED SHARES

The total number of shares of stock which the corporation shall have authority to issue is [NUMBER, e.g., 10,000,000] shares of Common Stock, each with a par value of [PAR VALUE, e.g., $0.0001] per share. All shares of Common Stock shall be of one class and shall have equal rights, preferences, and privileges in all respects, including voting rights, dividend rights, and liquidation preferences, unless otherwise specified in a Certificate of Designations filed for any future series of preferred stock.

The Board of Directors is expressly authorized, to the fullest extent permitted by law, to issue shares of Common Stock from time to time for such consideration as the Board may deem appropriate. The Board may also, by resolution, establish and designate one or more series of Preferred Stock, and fix the number of shares and the relative rights, preferences, and limitations of each such series, without further stockholder approval, provided such actions are consistent with the General Corporation Law of Delaware and any limitations set forth in these Articles or the Bylaws.

ARTICLE V: INCORPORATOR

The name and mailing address of the incorporator are: [INCORPORATOR NAME], [INCORPORATOR ADDRESS]. The incorporator's sole duty in this capacity is to execute and file these Articles of Incorporation with the Secretary of State of Delaware. Upon the filing of these Articles, the corporate existence shall commence, and the incorporator's role shall largely conclude, transferring authority to the initial Board of Directors.

Following the effectiveness of these Articles, the incorporator shall take all necessary steps to organize the corporation, which typically includes holding an organizational meeting to adopt bylaws, elect initial directors, and transact any other business necessary to complete the organization of the corporation. The incorporator may then resign, and the corporation will proceed under the governance of its Board of Directors and officers.

ARTICLE VI: LIMITATION OF DIRECTOR LIABILITY

To the fullest extent permitted by the General Corporation Law of Delaware as it now exists or may hereafter be amended, a director of the corporation shall not be personally liable to the corporation or its stockholders for monetary damages for breach of fiduciary duty as a director. This provision is intended to provide directors with robust protection against personal liability for actions taken in good faith in their corporate capacity, thereby encouraging qualified individuals to serve on the Board.

This Article VI shall not eliminate or limit the liability of a director (i) for any breach of the director's duty of loyalty to the corporation or its stockholders, (ii) for acts or omissions not in good faith or which involve intentional misconduct or a knowing violation of law, (iii) under Section 174 of the General Corporation Law of Delaware (relating to unlawful dividends or stock repurchases), or (iv) for any transaction from which the director derived an improper personal benefit. Any repeal or modification of this Article VI shall not adversely affect any right or protection of a director of the corporation existing at the time of such repeal or modification with respect to acts or omissions occurring prior to such repeal or modification.

ARTICLE VII: EFFECTIVE DATE

These Articles of Incorporation shall become effective upon the date of filing with the Secretary of State of the State of Delaware, or such later date as may be specified herein, not to exceed 90 days from the date of filing. The filing date marks the official commencement of the corporation's legal existence and its recognition as a distinct legal entity under Delaware law, enabling it to commence business operations and enter into contracts.

The effective date signifies the point at which the corporation acquires all the rights, powers, and privileges of a duly organized Delaware corporation. From this date forward, the corporation is subject to all applicable provisions of the General Corporation Law of Delaware, its own Articles of Incorporation, and its Bylaws, and is authorized to issue shares, elect directors, and conduct its affairs as a corporate entity.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned incorporator has executed these Articles of Incorporation this [DAY] day of [MONTH], [YEAR].

[INCORPORATOR NAME]

Incorporator

BYLAWS
OF [CORPORATION NAME]

These Bylaws govern the internal affairs of [CORPORATION NAME] (the "Corporation"), a corporation organized under the General Corporation Law of the State of Delaware, and are adopted by the Incorporator or the initial Board of Directors to establish the rules and procedures for the Corporation's operation, management, and governance. They are subordinate to the Corporation's Articles of Incorporation and the General Corporation Law of Delaware, and in the event of any conflict, the Articles of Incorporation or applicable law shall prevail.

These Bylaws may be amended, altered, or repealed, and new Bylaws may be adopted, in accordance with the provisions set forth herein. All actions taken by the Corporation, its directors, officers, and stockholders shall be in strict compliance with these Bylaws, ensuring orderly and lawful conduct of corporate business and the protection of stakeholder interests. Any interpretation of these Bylaws shall be consistent with the Corporation's Articles of Incorporation and the General Corporation Law of Delaware.

ARTICLE I: CORPORATE NAME AND OFFICE

Section 1.1. Name.

The name of the Corporation is [CORPORATION NAME]. This name shall be used for all legal and business purposes, and any change to this name must be effected through an amendment to the Corporation's Articles of Incorporation, filed with the Secretary of State of Delaware, as well as an update to these Bylaws. The Corporation shall ensure that its name is clearly displayed on all official documents and at its principal place of business.

The Corporation shall operate under this name and maintain its legal identity as established by its Articles of Incorporation. All contracts, agreements, and other legal instruments entered into by the Corporation shall clearly identify the Corporation by its full legal name, ensuring proper legal recognition and enforceability. Any use of trade names or fictitious names must comply with applicable state and federal regulations.

Section 1.2. Principal Office.

The principal office of the Corporation shall be located at [PRINCIPAL OFFICE ADDRESS, e.g., 123 Main Street, Anytown, CA 90210], or at such other place within or without the State of Delaware as the Board of Directors may from time to time designate. This location serves as the primary administrative and operational center for the Corporation's business activities, where its main records are typically maintained.

The Board of Directors has the authority to change the principal office location as deemed necessary for the efficient operation of the Corporation, provided that proper notice is given to relevant parties and any required regulatory filings are made. Such a change does not necessitate an amendment to the Articles of Incorporation, but it may require updates to various corporate records and communications to reflect the new address.

ARTICLE II: SHAREHOLDERS

Section 2.1. Annual Meetings.

An annual meeting of the stockholders shall be held each year at such date, time, and place, either within or without the State of Delaware, as shall be designated by the Board of Directors. The primary purpose of the annual meeting shall be for the election of directors and for the transaction of such other business as may properly come before the meeting. Failure to hold the annual meeting at the designated time shall not work any forfeiture or dissolution of the Corporation.

The Board of Directors shall provide reasonable notice of the annual meeting to all stockholders entitled to vote, in accordance with these Bylaws and applicable law. Business transacted at the annual meeting shall be limited to those matters set forth in the notice of meeting or matters otherwise properly brought before the meeting in accordance with these Bylaws and the rules of procedure adopted by the Board of Directors. The Board may postpone or reschedule any previously scheduled annual meeting.

Section 2.2. Special Meetings.

Special meetings of the stockholders, for any purpose or purposes, may be called by the Board of Directors, the President, or by the holders of not less than [PERCENTAGE, e.g., twenty percent (20%)] of all the shares of the Corporation entitled to vote at the meeting. The call for a special meeting shall state the purpose or purposes for which the meeting is called, and the business transacted at any special meeting shall be limited to the purposes stated in the notice of the meeting.

Upon receipt of a written request for a special meeting from eligible stockholders, the Secretary shall promptly call such meeting to be held at a reasonable time and date. The Board of Directors shall determine the location of any special meeting, which may be held within or without the State of Delaware. Notice of any special meeting shall be given in the same manner as for annual meetings, specifying the purpose of the meeting.

Section 2.3. Notice of Meetings.

Written notice of the annual meeting or any special meeting of stockholders shall be given not less than ten (10) nor more than sixty (60) days before the date of the meeting to each stockholder entitled to vote at such meeting. The notice shall specify the place, date, and hour of the meeting, and, in the case of a special meeting, the purpose or purposes for which the meeting is called. Notice may be given personally, by mail, or by electronic transmission.

If mailed, notice shall be deemed to be given when deposited in the United States mail, postage prepaid, directed to the stockholder at his or her address as it appears on the records of the Corporation. If sent by electronic transmission, notice shall be deemed given when directed to the stockholder's electronic mail address. An affidavit of the Secretary or an Assistant Secretary that such notice has been given shall, in the absence of fraud, be prima facie evidence of the facts therein stated.

Section 2.4. Quorum.

Except as otherwise provided by law or by the Articles of Incorporation, the holders of a majority of the stock issued and outstanding and entitled to vote at the meeting, present in person or represented by proxy, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business at all meetings of the stockholders. If a quorum is not present, the meeting may be adjourned from time to time by the affirmative vote of a majority of the shares present in person or represented by proxy, without further notice other than announcement at the meeting.

Once a quorum is established at a meeting, it shall not be broken by the subsequent withdrawal of stockholders from the meeting. Unless otherwise required by law or the Articles of Incorporation, the affirmative vote of the majority of shares present in person or represented by proxy at the meeting and entitled to vote on the subject matter shall be the act of the stockholders, provided a quorum is present. Abstentions and broker non-votes shall be treated as shares present for quorum purposes but not as votes cast for or against a proposal.

Section 2.5. Voting.

Each stockholder shall be entitled to one vote for each share of capital stock held by such stockholder. All elections of directors shall be by plurality vote. All other matters shall be decided by the affirmative vote of a majority of the shares present in person or represented by proxy at the meeting and entitled to vote on the subject matter, unless a different vote is required by law, the Articles of Incorporation, or these Bylaws. Voting may be by voice vote or by ballot as determined by the chairperson of the meeting.

Stockholders may vote in person or by proxy. Proxies shall be in writing, dated, and signed by the stockholder or his or her authorized attorney-in-fact, and filed with the Secretary of the Corporation before or at the time of the meeting. No proxy shall be voted or acted upon after three years from its date, unless the proxy provides for a longer period. The Board of Directors may establish procedures for the receipt and validation of proxies, including electronic proxies, consistent with Delaware law.

ARTICLE III: BOARD OF DIRECTORS

Section 3.1. Number, Election, Term.

The number of directors constituting the entire Board shall be not less than [MINIMUM NUMBER, e.g., one (1)] nor more than [MAXIMUM NUMBER, e.g., nine (9)], as determined from time to time by resolution of the Board of Directors or by the stockholders. The directors shall be elected at the annual meeting of the stockholders and shall hold office until the next annual meeting of stockholders and until their successors are duly elected and qualified, or until their earlier resignation, removal, or death.

Directors need not be stockholders. The Board of Directors may, by resolution, establish different classes of directors with staggered terms, if permitted by the Articles of Incorporation and Delaware law. Each director shall perform their duties in good faith, in a manner the director reasonably believes to be in the best interests of the Corporation, and with such care as an ordinarily prudent person in a like position would use under similar circumstances.

Section 3.2. Powers.

The business and affairs of the Corporation shall be managed by or under the direction of the Board of Directors. The Board shall have all powers necessary or appropriate for the management of the Corporation's business, including but not limited to, the power to elect officers, declare dividends, authorize the issuance of stock, incur indebtedness, and adopt, amend, or repeal Bylaws, subject to any limitations in the Articles of Incorporation or Delaware law. The Board may delegate certain powers to committees or officers, but ultimate oversight responsibility remains with the Board.

The Board of Directors is responsible for setting the strategic direction of the Corporation, overseeing its financial performance, and ensuring compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. Directors are fiduciaries of the Corporation and its stockholders, and their decisions must be made with due care and loyalty. The Board may establish policies and procedures for the conduct of the Corporation's business, and may retain advisors as necessary to assist in its duties.

Section 3.3. Meetings.

Regular meetings of the Board of Directors may be held at such times and places, within or without the State of Delaware, as the Board may from time to time determine. Special meetings of the Board may be called by the President, the Chairman of the Board, or by any two directors, on at least two (2) days' notice to each director, either personally, by mail, or by electronic transmission. Notice of regular meetings need not be given if the time and place are fixed by resolution of the Board.

Meetings of the Board of Directors may be held by means of conference telephone or other communications equipment by means of which all persons participating in the meeting can hear each other, and participation in a meeting pursuant to this provision shall constitute presence in person at such meeting. The Board may also act without a meeting if all directors consent in writing to such action, as further detailed in these Bylaws.

Section 3.4. Quorum.

At all meetings of the Board of Directors, a majority of the total number of directors shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. If a quorum is not present at any meeting of the Board, the directors present may adjourn the meeting from time to time without notice other than announcement at the meeting, until a quorum shall be present. No business requiring a vote shall be transacted in the absence of a quorum.

The act of a majority of the directors present at a meeting at which a quorum is present shall be the act of the Board of Directors, unless a greater number is required by law, the Articles of Incorporation, or these Bylaws. Directors may not vote by proxy at Board meetings. Any director who has a conflict of interest in a matter under consideration should recuse themselves from the discussion and vote on that matter, in accordance with the Corporation's conflict of interest policy.

ARTICLE IV: OFFICERS

Section 4.1. Number and Titles.

The officers of the Corporation shall consist of a President, a Secretary, and a Treasurer. The Board of Directors may also elect or appoint such other officers, including a Chairman of the Board, one or more Vice Presidents, Assistant Secretaries, and Assistant Treasurers, as it may deem desirable. Any number of offices may be held by the same person, unless prohibited by law or the Articles of Incorporation. The Board shall determine the duties and responsibilities of all officers.

The officers shall be elected by the Board of Directors at its first meeting following each annual meeting of stockholders, or as soon thereafter as convenient. Each officer shall hold office until his or her successor is elected and qualified or until his or her earlier resignation or removal. The Board of Directors may, from time to time, create new officer positions or combine existing ones, and define their respective duties and authorities as necessary for the efficient management of the Corporation.

Section 4.2. Duties of Officers.

The officers shall have such duties and responsibilities as are customarily incident to their respective offices and such other duties as may be assigned to them from time to time by the Board of Directors. The President shall be the chief executive officer of the Corporation and shall have general supervision over the business and affairs of the Corporation, subject to the control of the Board of Directors. The Secretary shall keep the minutes of all meetings of the stockholders and the Board of Directors, and shall be responsible for all corporate records and official correspondence. The Treasurer shall have custody of the corporate funds and securities and shall keep full and accurate accounts of receipts and disbursements.

Each officer shall perform their duties in a diligent and faithful manner, upholding the best interests of the Corporation and its stockholders. In the absence or disability of any officer, the Board of Directors may delegate the powers and duties of such officer to any other officer or to any director. The Board may also require officers to provide bonds for the faithful performance of their duties, in such sums and with such sureties as the Board may determine.

ARTICLE V: INDEMNIFICATION

Section 5.1. Right to Indemnification.

The Corporation shall indemnify any person who was or is a party or is threatened to be made a party to any threatened, pending, or completed action, suit, or proceeding, whether civil, criminal, administrative, or investigative (other than an action by or in the right of the Corporation) by reason of the fact that he or she is or was a director, officer, employee, or agent of the Corporation, or is or was serving at the request of the Corporation as a director, officer, employee, or agent of another corporation, partnership, joint venture, trust, or other enterprise, against expenses (including attorneys' fees), judgments, fines, and amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred by him or her in connection with such action, suit, or proceeding, if he or she acted in good faith and in a manner he or she reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interests of the Corporation, and, with respect to any criminal action or proceeding, had no reasonable cause to believe his or her conduct was unlawful.

The Corporation shall indemnify any person who was or is a party or is threatened to be made a party to any threatened, pending, or completed action or suit by or in the right of the Corporation to procure a judgment in its favor by reason of the fact that he or she is or was a director, officer, employee, or agent of the Corporation, or is or was serving at the request of the Corporation as a director, officer, employee, or agent of another corporation, partnership, joint venture, trust, or other enterprise against expenses (including attorneys' fees) actually and reasonably incurred by him or her in connection with the defense or settlement of such action or suit if he or she acted in good faith and in a manner he or she reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interests of the Corporation, except that no indemnification shall be made in respect of any claim, issue, or matter as to which such person shall have been adjudged to be liable to the Corporation unless and only to the extent that the Court of Chancery or the court in which such action or suit was brought shall determine upon application that, despite the adjudication of liability but in view of all the circumstances of the case, such person is fairly and reasonably entitled to indemnity for such expenses which the Court of Chancery or such other court shall deem proper.

Section 5.2. Advancement of Expenses.

Expenses (including attorneys' fees) incurred by an officer or director in defending any civil, criminal, administrative, or investigative action, suit, or proceeding may be paid by the Corporation in advance of the final disposition of such action, suit, or proceeding upon receipt of an undertaking by the person to repay such amount if it shall ultimately be determined that he or she is not entitled to be indemnified by the Corporation as authorized in this Article V. Such undertaking shall be an unlimited general obligation of the person receiving the advance and may be unsecured.

The Board of Directors shall have the authority to determine the terms and conditions under which such advancements are made, including the requirement for a written undertaking. This advancement of expenses is intended to ensure that directors and officers are not financially burdened during the pendency of litigation or investigations, thereby encouraging qualified individuals to serve the Corporation. The Corporation may also purchase and maintain insurance on behalf of any person who is or was a director, officer, employee, or agent of the Corporation against any liability asserted against him or her and incurred by him or her in any such capacity, whether or not the Corporation would have the power to indemnify him or her against such liability under the provisions of this Article V.

ARTICLE VI: CAPITAL STOCK

Section 6.1. Certificates.

The shares of the Corporation shall be represented by certificates, or shall be uncertificated shares. Each certificate for shares shall be in such form as the Board of Directors may determine and shall be signed by the Chairman of the Board, the President, or a Vice President and by the Secretary or an Assistant Secretary, or the Treasurer or an Assistant Treasurer. The certificate shall state the name of the Corporation, that it is organized under the laws of Delaware, the name of the person to whom issued, and the number and class of shares represented thereby. All certificates shall bear the corporate seal or a facsimile thereof.

The Board of Directors may provide by resolution that some or all of any or all classes or series of the Corporation's stock shall be uncertificated shares. Any such resolution shall not apply to shares represented by a certificate until such certificate is surrendered to the Corporation. Any uncertificated shares shall be evidenced by a book-entry system maintained by the Corporation or its transfer agent, and a written statement shall be sent to the holder of such uncertificated shares within a reasonable time after the issuance or transfer of such shares, providing information required by Delaware law.

Section 6.2. Transfer of Shares.

Transfers of shares of the capital stock of the Corporation shall be made only on the books of the Corporation by the holder of record thereof, or by his or her attorney thereunto duly authorized, upon surrender of the certificate or proper evidence of transfer for such shares, properly endorsed or accompanied by a duly executed stock power. The Corporation shall be entitled to treat the holder of record of any share or shares of stock as the holder in fact thereof and accordingly shall not be bound to recognize any equitable or other claim to or interest in such share or shares on the part of any other person, whether or not it shall have express or other notice thereof, except as expressly provided by the laws of Delaware.

The Board of Directors may appoint a transfer agent and/or registrar to maintain the records of stock ownership and facilitate transfers. The Corporation shall not be obligated to transfer shares until any applicable restrictions on transfer, including those imposed by law, the Articles of Incorporation, or any agreements to which the Corporation is a party, have been satisfied. The Board may establish reasonable rules and regulations for the transfer of shares, consistent with applicable law and these Bylaws.

ARTICLE VII: GENERAL PROVISIONS

Section 7.1. Corporate Seal.

The corporate seal shall have inscribed thereon the name of the Corporation and the words "Corporate Seal, Delaware." The seal may be used by causing it or a facsimile thereof to be impressed or affixed or reproduced or otherwise. The use of the corporate seal is not mandatory under Delaware law for the validity of corporate acts, but it may be used on official documents as a mark of authenticity and corporate authority.

The Secretary shall be the custodian of the corporate seal. The Board of Directors may authorize other officers to use the seal in connection with their duties. The absence of the corporate seal on any document shall not impair the validity of such document or the transaction contemplated thereby, provided the document is otherwise properly authorized and executed by the Corporation.

Section 7.2. Fiscal Year.

The fiscal year of the Corporation shall be determined by resolution of the Board of Directors. Unless otherwise determined, the fiscal year shall end on the [MONTH AND DAY, e.g., 31st day of December] of each year. The fiscal year establishes the accounting period for the Corporation's financial reporting and tax purposes.

The Board of Directors may change the fiscal year at any time, provided that such change is properly documented and communicated to relevant stakeholders, including taxing authorities. Any change to the fiscal year must comply with applicable accounting standards and tax regulations, and may require adjustments to financial reporting cycles.

Section 7.3. Waiver of Notice.

Whenever notice is required to be given under any provision of the General Corporation Law of Delaware or the Articles of Incorporation or these Bylaws, a written waiver thereof, signed by the person or persons entitled to said notice, whether before or after the time stated therein, shall be deemed equivalent to notice. Attendance of a person at a meeting shall constitute a waiver of notice of such meeting, except when the person attends for the express purpose of objecting, at the beginning of the meeting, to the transaction of any business because the meeting is not lawfully called or convened.

Neither the business to be transacted at, nor the purpose of, any regular or special meeting of the stockholders, directors, or committee of directors need be specified in any written waiver of notice unless so required by the Articles of Incorporation or these Bylaws. This provision allows for flexibility in meeting notice requirements, particularly in situations where all parties are aware of and consent to the meeting, ensuring that procedural technicalities do not unduly impede corporate actions.

ARTICLE VIII: AMENDMENTS

These Bylaws may be altered, amended, or repealed, and new Bylaws may be adopted, by the affirmative vote of a majority of the Board of Directors at any regular or special meeting of the Board, provided that notice of the proposed alteration, amendment, or repeal is contained in the notice of such meeting. The power to alter, amend, or repeal the Bylaws and to adopt new Bylaws is also vested in the stockholders, who may exercise such power at any annual or special meeting by the affirmative vote of a majority of the shares of stock entitled to vote thereon.

Any Bylaw adopted by the Board of Directors may be altered, amended, or repealed by the stockholders. Stockholders retain the ultimate authority over the Bylaws, ensuring that the Board's actions are subject to stockholder oversight. This dual amendment power provides flexibility for the Board to make necessary operational adjustments while preserving the stockholders' fundamental right to govern the Corporation's internal affairs. Any amendment must be consistent with the Articles of Incorporation and the General Corporation Law of Delaware.

ADOPTED by the Board of Directors on this [DAY] day of [MONTH], [YEAR].

[NAME OF PRESIDENT]

President

[NAME OF SECRETARY]

Secretary
